nodes.bodyText: is this name a recursive acronym?
the SC prefix is clearly a convention, but what does it stand for?

SocketCreator.  I wanted to rename all of this since the purpose of SocketCreator is to add TLS support but it would kill backward-compatibility tests to change SocketCreator's name.  Maybe we can do that in Geode 2.0.
an aside,  SINGLETON sticks out - but doesn't seem to be the kind of singleton we want to be rid of....
I know it was existing, but add could just be address... a nit I know
I really like the clarity here!!!
we might want to expunge this literal bug number and replace with the issue/feature, if that's not what the rest of comment is already doing...
I don't see this method called anywhere. Is this dead code?
Ah ok I see we're calling getHostString() to avoid reverse-lookup if an address was originally specified (instead of a hostname/FQDN).
…and this call (to SocketCreator.getHostName()) is ok because the reverse lookup is cached, right?

getSocketInetAddress() will try to resolve the hostname stored in addr, by constructing an InetSocketAddress from the hostname and port. Address resolution boils down to utimately calling InetAddress.getByName(hostname)

Yes, that's what the LocatorAddress method was supposed to do.  I renamed LocatorAddress to HostAndPort since it can hold arbitrary addresses, not just locator addresses.  For your PR you can bypass getSocketInetAddress and just get the hostname since that's all you need for the SNIServerName parameter.

…then, if address resolution failed, we try InetAddress.getByName() again. With the exact same hostname.
Two things:

I don't see how this second address resolution will ever work if the first one failed (barring some rare race with DNS data)
In the case where we enter the conditional at line 61, we end up with sockaddr referring to an InetSocketAddress that has a null address and no hostname at all. Wheres if we do not enter the conditional sockaddr refers to an InetSocketAddress that has both hostname and port.

Should we remove this conditional entirely?

Ah now I see that line 61 throws an UnknownHostException if address resolution fails. This, while quirky, is reasonable. Inasmuch as this logic has been in the product a long time, I'm ok with leaving it as-is.

I had to do some recollection on this one Bill.
HostAndPort.getSocketInetAddress() is required to resolve hostnames if possible.  It's supposed to hold onto hostname:port pairs and leave the name unresolved until this method is called.
Yes, the second resolution will fail 100% of the time, but it will give us the expected UnknownHostException with the correct text.  Without that lookup there was at least one test failure that asserted that it should get this exception when attempting to use an invalid host name.
